text: I'm joined now by Debbie
wasserman-schultz chairman of the
Democratic National Committee so thank
you for joining us you're welcome
are you better off than you were four
years ago question if there's been some
puzzling over the last several days that
it seems like there are certain people
who are sort of not ready for that
question which seems like a fairly easy
to anticipate question what do you what
do you think about that why were people
sort of not ready for that question
well I I don't agree that we weren't
ready the answer is absolutely and if
you you'll only to look at what
President Obama only to look at what
President Obama inherited from President
Bush I mean in the previous six months
in him taking office the economy lost
three and a half million jobs and when
he took office we were hemorrhaging
750,000 jobs a month thanks to his
policies like the Recovery Act that put
a tourniquet on that bleeding and
allowed us to begin to get things turned
around and then he focused on making
sure we could rescue the American
automobile industry and invest in the
middle class we now have had 29 straight
months of job growth in the private
sector and a resurgence in manufacturing
and manufacturing jobs so we're
definitely better off than when
President Obama first took office and
we've got a ways to go but we need to
keep moving forward
so is your jump is the number-one goal
for this finish this week to provide a
more affirmative vision of what the last
three-and-a-half years has been like I
think there has been some frustration
among some Democrats that there hasn't
been a more forceful
kind of defense of not necessarily from
you but just generally for from what the

I think you'll see President Obama on

conversation with the American people
about where we were when he took office
and about where we need to go how we
know it needs to make sure that if you
work hard and play by the rules that
everyone in America has a chance for
success and that we can ensure that the

an economy built from the middle class
out and bottom up not the top down
failed policies of the past that Mitt
Romney and Paul Ryan want to take us
back to but crashed our economy you
worry at all about that we're not
overconfident but I can tell you that we
are proud that we've stood up the most
significant dynamic grassroots
presidential campaign and this week
we're putting on the most open
accessible Community Oriented nominating
convention in political history because
we use this condemn these conventions as
an organizing tool in 2008 we actually
signed up 25,000 volunteers on the day
that President Obama accepted our
party's nomination and Invesco Field and
he's going to accept our nomination and
the Bank of America Stadium and by the
tens of thousands on Thursday and
they'll lay out the vision and the
specifics about how important it is that
we continue to fight for the middle
class and working families do you see
this organizing tool as a way of sort of
trying to if not replicate the
excitement 2008 which is probably

about trying to sort of match that make

think Americans are proud of the
progress that we've made like the
Affordable Care Act that insurance
insurance companies can't drop you or
deny you coverage like the 18 different
tax breaks for small businesses like the
focus on investing and education so we
can out-educate and out-innovate our

they don't want to go backward they want
to move forward and so that's what I
think is exciting people and President
Obama's vision to continue to keep
fighting to improve our economy the
Republicans basically are trying to push

with increasing taxes for the middle
class to pay for budget-busting tax
breaks for millionaires and billionaires
it doesn't make any sense
and and I think the choice is going to
be pretty clear but let me tell you
we're taking nothing for granted a

you started off there
in between 46 making point that a

now I know that we're more than half the

there's a big difference between the

there's a good reason that President

it's action then President Obama has
